WEEK_1: Understand the systematic design process
Apply the one task one function rule
Design programs for moderately complex tasks
WEEK_2: Write readable and well organized code
Document programs clearly
Construct effective tests for programs
WEEK_3: Relate information to appropriate data representations
Design data representations for moderately complex problems
Describe the information encoded in a data definition
WEEK_4: Identify correspondences between data definitions and program structure
Predict how changes to a data definition affect related programs
WEEK_5: Recognize repeated code suitable for abstraction
Create abstractions that replace repetitive code
Use existing libraries or code to design new programs

WEEK_1: Identify data abstractions from a small problem description
Specify behaviors for chosen abstractions
Write unit tests that validate specification before coding
WEEK_2: Implement programs in Java using appropriate abstraction structures
Make implementation choices for internal program design
Achieve basic code coverage using test driven design
WEEK_3: Apply object oriented design principles including coupling, cohesion and single responsibility
Use substitution principles and basic design patterns
Design robust software using modular components
WEEK_4: Analyze an existing codebase using static and dynamic modeling
Identify design idioms and design patterns within code
Interpret behavior and structure of medium sized programs
WEEK_5: Evolve an existing codebase by extending or modifying behavior
Use alteration, subtyping or composition to implement changes
Maintain program integrity while evolving architecture

WEEK_1: Evaluate software engineering processes and justify their tradeoffs
Identify functional requirements and quality attributes from a problem description
Describe requirements succinctly and precisely
WEEK_2: Refine and deconstruct functional requirements
Formulate complete and precise quality attribute specifications
Differentiate between functional and nonfunctional requirements
WEEK_3: Devise high level software designs for given requirements
Devise low level software designs aligned with future evolutionary needs
Justify design choices with respect to requirements and constraints
WEEK_4: Iteratively derive implementations from a design of moderate complexity
Identify emergent design implications during implementation
Apply code level restructuring to facilitate future changes
WEEK_5: Implement software designs while considering ethical implications
Incorporate security considerations into code level decisions
Apply appropriate software process and methodological approaches

WEEK_1: Analyze linear algorithm performance
Prove correctness of linear algorithms
Evaluate design choices in simple algorithmic solutions
WEEK_2: Explain linear sorting methods
Implement linked lists, stacks, and queues
Compare tradeoffs of basic linear data structures
WEEK_3: Analyze recursive algorithm performance
Prove correctness of recursive algorithms
Design recursive solutions to computational problems
WEEK_4: Apply recursive sorting techniques
Describe fundamental tree concepts
Construct simple tree based structures
WEEK_5: Perform standard tree traversals
Implement binary search trees
Evaluate correctness and efficiency of BST operations

WEEK_1: Formulate clear computational problems from vague descriptions
Recognize when algorithmic problem formulation is incomplete
Translate informal tasks into precise algorithmic goals
WEEK_2: Identify algorithm design techniques such as brute force, divide and conquer, greedy, and dynamic programming
Classify a given algorithm by its underlying design technique
Explain why a particular design strategy matches a given problem
WEEK_3: Evaluate which algorithm design techniques can solve a problem efficiently
Select appropriate data structures to support algorithmic solutions
Justify the efficiency of chosen strategies
WEEK_4: Implement solutions based on specified design techniques
Translate high level algorithm strategies into working implementations
Debug and validate algorithmic implementations for correctness
WEEK_5: Apply asymptotic notation to analyze running time
Use recurrence relations to derive time bounds
Establish upper and lower running time bounds for algorithms

WEEK_1: Compare growth of power, logarithmic, exponential, and trigonometric functions
Sketch basic curves using key function properties
Understand the concept of a limit
WEEK_2: Evaluate limits and identify horizontal and vertical asymptotes
Determine continuity of functions
Compute slopes of lines and relate them to rates of change
WEEK_3: Define and compute derivatives
Find tangent lines and linear approximations
Apply properties of the exponential function
WEEK_4: Apply linearity, power, product, and quotient rules for derivatives
Differentiate trigonometric functions
Use rules of differentiation to compute complex derivatives
WEEK_5: Apply the chain rule to composite functions
Use logarithmic differentiation
Perform implicit differentiation

WEEK_1: Interpret definite integrals as signed area
Compute area functions using geometry
Approximate areas using Riemann sums and trapezoidal rule
Sketch area functions
Apply the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus Part 1
Differentiate functions defined by integrals
Manipulate sigma notation and express sums symbolically
WEEK_2: Use arithmetic and endpoint properties of definite integrals
Define indefinite integrals and distinguish them from definite integrals
Apply the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus Part 2
Find antiderivatives of basic and composite functions
Solve applied problems requiring integration methods
Derive and apply Leibniz’s rule
WEEK_3: Relate substitution to the chain rule
Evaluate integrals using substitution for definite and indefinite cases
Choose effective substitutions for simplifying integrals
Compute integrals requiring algebraic manipulation
Evaluate trigonometric integrals using identities
WEEK_4: Differentiate between direct and inverse substitution
Apply trigonometric substitution to compute integrals
Select appropriate trigonometric substitutions based on structure
Use partial fractions to integrate rational functions
Express volumes using definite integrals
Compute volumes using disks and cross sections
WEEK_5: Apply integration by parts to definite and indefinite integrals
Identify when integration by parts is appropriate
Select effective choices for u and dv

WEEK_1: Understand the scientific method
Identify characteristics of life and major themes in biology
Explain Darwin’s voyage and evolution by natural selection
Describe evidence for evolution
Interpret the phylogenetic tree of life
WEEK_2: Explain mechanisms of evolution beyond natural selection
Differentiate species concepts and nomenclature
Describe species and speciation
Analyze species interactions and ecological niches
Explain symbiosis and predation
WEEK_3: Describe adaptation to the environment
Explain community ecology and food webs
Understand chemistry of water and basic biological chemistry
Describe organic molecules including carbohydrates and lipids
Explain protein structure and DNA
WEEK_4: Describe biological diversity and prokaryotic cell structure
Explain eukaryotic cell structure
Explain endosymbiotic theory
Describe cytoskeleton structure and function
WEEK_5: Summarize major events in Earth’s biological history

WEEK_1: Explain gene and chromosome structure
Describe the role of chromosomes in heredity
Interpret basic genetic terminology
WEEK_2: Describe cell cycle stages including mitosis
Explain meiosis and its role in generating variation
Compare mitosis and meiosis
WEEK_3: Apply Mendelian principles to inheritance problems
Predict genetic outcomes using Punnett analysis
WEEK_4: Analyze pedigrees to infer inheritance patterns
Apply Mendelian rules to human genetic cases
WEEK_5: Review genetics concepts in preparation for Midterm 1

WEEK_1: Distinguish covalent, polar covalent, and ionic bonding
Draw Lewis structures for polyatomic species
Represent resonance structures accurately
Assign formal charges, oxidation states, and partial charges
WEEK_2: Predict molecular shapes using VSEPR
Determine molecular polarity
Relate shape to physical and chemical properties
WEEK_3: Describe wave-like properties of matter
Apply probability concepts to electrons
Recognize when electrons behave as waves
Explain the Heisenberg uncertainty principle
Solve basic quantum mechanical particle-in-a-box problems
WEEK_4: Analyze one-electron atomic species
Interpret orbital diagrams for s, p, and d orbitals
Explain energy levels in one-electron species
WEEK_5: Describe the nature of light
Explain the photoelectric effect
Relate absorption and emission to quantum transitions
Interpret atomic spectroscopy data

WEEK_1: Interpret phase diagrams for one component systems
Identify phase transitions and equilibrium points on phase diagrams
WEEK_2: Define equilibrium constants for chemical and physical changes
Relate equilibrium constants to activities
Apply Hess’s law to thermochemical equations
Explain energy, work, and the first law of thermodynamics
WEEK_3: Explain entropy and the second and third laws of thermodynamics
Predict spontaneity using entropy changes
Interpret standard entropy values
WEEK_4: Relate free energy to equilibrium constants
Predict spontaneity from Gibbs free energy
Use ΔG = ΔG° + RT ln Q to evaluate reaction conditions
Apply the Nernst equation to electrochemical systems
WEEK_5: Interpret reaction coordinate diagrams
Determine rate laws for first and second order reactions
Predict how temperature, concentration, and activation energy affect reaction rates
